newsitem.title: UK: Tanker rates seen steady to weaker in Q2 - MSI.
newsitem.headline: Tanker rates seen steady to weaker in Q2 - MSI.

text.p: Tanker freight rates are likely to hold or even edge lower in the next quarter after their recent rise, Independent shipping consultant Maritime Strategies International(MSI) said on Monday.
However, MSI said VLCC and Suezmax earnings would rise again in the summer.

"There were rate gains in all tanker sectors in January, but Aframaxes and product tankers were the star performers with average earnings reaching their highest levels since mid-1991," MSI said in its monthly Freight Forecaster analysis.

MSI said the rapid improvement in tanker earnings was in part due to strong seasonal demand which boosted world crude oil production to 74.8 million barrels per day (bpd) -- up 900,000 bpd on December levels.
It said that average Very large crude carrier (VLCC) earnings jumped by $6,000 per day in January to $19,200 with further gains at the beginning of February.
But it said that as the benefits of increased seasonal demand and the stimulus of the first full month of Iraqi crude oil exports moderated, it "anticipated a lull in rates in the second quarter."
"However, the summer surge in westbound longhaul demand due to North Sea oil platform maintenance will push earnings close to $25,000 per day in July," it said of VLCC earnings.

The positive outlook for earnings could force charterers to be more active in the time charter market, MSI said, adding that softening newbuilding prices would increase the probability of a VLCC ordering boom.

MSI said it expected the Suezmax market to build on its growth over the last 12 months to average earnings in January of more than $20,000 per day. New highs for 130,000 dwt vessels would be reached later in the first half of 1997.
"The upside potential of the Suezmax sector has been capped by the now well established competition from VLCCs on Suezmax trades," it said.

However, MSI added Suezmax owners are also showing a willingness to exploit new opportunities. It gave examples of a regular export trade developing from Venezuela and potential opportunities into the US West Coast to meet a shortfall in supply caused by a slowdown in Alaskan production.
Average Aframax earnings fell back by mid February, from rapid gains to around $22,100 per day in January for 80,000 dwt vessels, MSI said.
"Nevertheless, Aframax rates continue to follow a seasonal pattern and MSI expects the peak period for North Sea oil platform maintenance during June to August will produce a downturn in rates."

Product freight rates have also followed seasonal patterns and MSI forecast earnings for 30,000 dwt vessels would fall back over the next six months from spot highs of $18,300 per day in January as gas oil inventories were rebuilt and U.S. refinery maintenance programmes started up.
MSI distributes full shipping earnings analyses with graphics and data via email on a monthly basis.
